facts.fact: San Juan is the capital and most populous city of Puerto Rico, founded by Spanish colonists in 1521.
Old San Juan is a UNESCO World Heritage Site with over 400 years of Spanish colonial architecture.
El Morro fortress, built in the 16th century, guarded San Juan Bay against attacks for over 400 years.
San Juan is the oldest continuously inhabited city under US jurisdiction.
The Port of San Juan is one of the busiest cruise ship ports in the Western Hemisphere.
Bayamón is the second-largest city in Puerto Rico, part of the San Juan metropolitan area.
Bayamón is known as the City of Cowboys due to its historical cattle ranching industry.
The Bacardí rum distillery, the largest premium rum distillery in the world, is located in Bayamón.
Carolina is the third-largest municipality in Puerto Rico and home to Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport.
Carolina is known as the Land of Giants for producing many notable athletes and tall residents.
Baseball legend Roberto Clemente was born in Carolina in 1934.
Ponce is the largest city in southern Puerto Rico, known as La Perla del Sur (The Pearl of the South).
The Ponce Museum of Art houses the largest art collection in the Caribbean.
Ponce's historic district contains some of the finest examples of Ponce Creole architecture.
The Parque de Bombas, a red and black striped firehouse from 1882, is Ponce's most iconic landmark.
Caguas is known as the Heart of Puerto Rico due to its central location in the island.
Caguas was founded in 1775 and named after the Taíno cacique Caguax.
The Caguas Botanical Garden features the largest collection of tropical plants in Puerto Rico.
Guaynabo is an affluent suburb of San Juan and one of the wealthiest municipalities in Puerto Rico.
The San Patricio shopping district in Guaynabo is one of the largest commercial areas in the Caribbean.
Mayagüez is the largest city on Puerto Rico's west coast, known as the Sultan of the West.
The University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez is the leading engineering school in the Caribbean.
Mayagüez hosted the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games.
Arecibo was home to the Arecibo Observatory, which had the world's largest single-dish radio telescope until its collapse in 2020.
The Arecibo Lighthouse and Historical Park offers views of the Atlantic Ocean and historical exhibits.
Arecibo is known as La Villa del Capitán Correa after a local hero who defended against British invasion.
Aguadilla is known for its beautiful beaches and was once home to Ramey Air Force Base.
Crash Boat Beach in Aguadilla is named after boats used to rescue downed pilots during WWII.
Christopher Columbus reportedly landed near Aguadilla during his second voyage in 1493.
Humacao is known as the Gray Pearl of the East and is a gateway to the eastern beaches.
The Humacao Nature Reserve protects important coastal wetlands and wildlife habitat.
Fajardo is the departure point for ferries to the islands of Vieques and Culebra.
The bioluminescent Laguna Grande in Fajardo glows at night due to millions of dinoflagellates.
Seven Seas Beach in Fajardo is consistently rated one of the best beaches in Puerto Rico.
Toa Baja is one of the oldest settlements in Puerto Rico, established in 1745.
The municipality takes its name from the Toa River and baja meaning lower in Spanish.
Toa Alta means Upper Toa, referring to its location upstream from Toa Baja.
Toa Alta is known as the City of the Taíno in honor of the indigenous people who once inhabited the area.
Trujillo Alto is a residential suburb east of San Juan with a growing population.
The Carraízo Dam in Trujillo Alto supplies much of the San Juan metro area's drinking water.
Vega Baja is known as the Melting Pot of Puerto Rico for its diverse cultural heritage.
Playa Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja is famous for its natural rock formations and pools.
Cayey sits in the mountains at 1,500 feet elevation, giving it a cooler climate than coastal cities.
The University of Puerto Rico at Cayey is located in the city, founded in 1967.
Isabela is known as the Garden of the Northwest for its agricultural production.
Jobos Beach in Isabela is one of Puerto Rico's premier surfing destinations.
Guayama is known as the City of Witches, a nickname stemming from colonial-era legends.
The Casa Cautiño Museum in Guayama showcases 19th-century Creole architecture and culture.
San Germán is the second-oldest European settlement in Puerto Rico, founded in 1511.
The Porta Coeli church in San Germán, built in 1606, is one of the oldest churches in the Americas.
Río Grande is the gateway to El Yunque National Forest, the only tropical rainforest in the US National Forest System.
Río Grande means Big River in Spanish, named for the rivers that flow through the municipality.
Cabo Rojo is known for its salt flats and the iconic Los Morrillos Lighthouse at the island's southwestern tip.
The Cabo Rojo National Wildlife Refuge protects important habitat for migratory birds.
Dorado is known for its luxury beach resorts and world-class golf courses.
The Dorado Beach Resort was developed by Laurance Rockefeller in the 1950s.
Utuado is located in Puerto Rico's mountainous interior and is known for its Taíno heritage.
The Caguana Indigenous Ceremonial Park in Utuado preserves pre-Columbian Taíno ball courts and petroglyphs.
